The number of hours of programming distributed has increased from
the four mentioned for 1950 to ten at the present time. These ten hours of
programming, necessitating the duplicating and shipping of more than 800
tape recordings a week, are for general adult audiences and for children's
our-of-school listening. In addition this year the Network will make avail¬
able 12 series of in-school radio programs for use in the classroom. These
series, requiring duplication and distribution of more than 3,000 tape
recordings (two programs to a reel), comprise 304 programs.
Although the NAEB TV engineer was not, under terms of our grant,
able to devote much time to problems of Radio Network operation, he was
able to provide some engineering supervision which resulted in better tech¬
nical quality. Also, for the past two years (until then only untrained per¬
sonnel was available) we have been fortunate in having as our assistant
network manager in charge of production a licensed broadcast engineer.
His constant maintenance of the duplicating equipment and his efforts to
upgrade the technical quality of duplicated programs have resulted in a
noticeable improvement in the qulaity of recordings distributed by the Net¬
work.
